title: Search shell history instantly with Ctrl + R
body: Press Ctrl + R and start typing to interactively search previously executed commands instead of scrolling with arrow keys.

title: Create command aliases to save time
body: Add lines like `alias ll='ls -la'` or `alias gs='git status'` to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc to shorten frequently used commands.

title: Use tmux to protect SSH workloads
body: Run long-running remote tasks inside tmux to avoid losing progress if your SSH connection drops.

title: Use `sudo !!` to rerun last command with root
body: If you forget sudo, run `sudo !!` to execute the last command again as root.

title: Navigate directories with pushd and popd
body: `pushd` temporarily switches directories while storing the current one; `popd` returns to it — great for multitasking.

title: Show disk usage of folders quickly
body: Run `du -sh *` inside a directory to see the sizes of each item in human-readable format.

title: View big files while they grow
body: Use `tail -f logfile.log` to monitor a file as new content is added.

title: Measure execution time of a command
body: Prefix a command with `time`, like `time ./script.sh`, to show execution duration and resource usage.

title: Pretty-print JSON in the terminal
body: Use `jq . file.json` or `echo '{...}' | jq .` for colorful formatted JSON output.

title: Repeat a command every second
body: Use `watch -n 1 <command>` to rerun and display command output repeatedly, useful for monitoring changes.

title: Extract tar archives with a single command
body: Instead of memorizing flags, use `tar xf archive.tar.gz`; tar auto-detects compression.

title: Generate random passwords from the terminal
body: Run `openssl rand -base64 32` to create a strong random password.

title: Check what's listening on every port
body: `sudo lsof -i -P -n | grep LISTEN` shows processes bound to TCP/UDP ports.

title: Batch rename files with rename
body: Use `rename 's/.txt/.md/' *.txt` to change file extensions instantly.

title: Use grep recursively in projects
body: `grep -R "text" .` searches all files under the current directory.

title: Use fzf for blazing-fast fuzzy search
body: `fzf` lets you search filenames, command history, git branches, and more interactively.

title: Quickly find recently modified files
body: `ls -lt` lists files sorted by modification time, newest first.

title: Find large files consuming disk space
body: `find / -type f -size +1G` finds files larger than 1GB anywhere in the system.

title: Copy SSH keys to remote server automatically
body: `ssh-copy-id user@server` adds your public key to authorized_keys for password-less login.

title: Transfer files between servers with SCP
body: `scp file user@server:/path` securely copies files over SSH.

title: Use rsync for fast backup and sync
body: Run `rsync -avh --progress src/ dest/` to synchronize directories efficiently.

title: Sort processes by memory in htop
body: In htop, press F6 to change sorting, then select RES to sort by memory usage.

title: Check Linux distribution and version
body: Run `cat /etc/os-release` to see distribution name, version, and codename.

title: Create a backup of installed packages
body: `apt list --installed > packages.txt` creates a list of all installed packages on Debian-based systems.

title: Auto-jump quickly between directories with zoxide
body: `z` or `zi` jumps to recently visited folders using frecency ranking.

title: Search command manual pages
body: Run `man -k <keyword>` to search man pages by topic instead of exact name.

title: Show what a command really runs
body: Use `type <command>` to check whether a command is an alias, builtin, function, or binary.

title: Show full command path
body: `which command` prints the exact executable being launched.

title: Kill processes by name instead of PID
body: `pkill <name>` sends a signal to all processes matching the name.

title: Synchronize system time with NTP
body: Use `timedatectl set-ntp true` to enable automatic time sync.

title: List open network ports with ss
body: Use `ss -tulpn` to see which processes are listening on which TCP and UDP ports.

title: Check current resource limits with ulimit
body: Run `ulimit -a` in your shell to see file size, open file, and process limits for your user.

title: Use history expansion to reuse arguments
body: Use `!$` for the last argument and `!*` for all arguments of the previous command, like `mkdir project && cd !$`.

title: Use brace expansion for multiple directories
body: Run `mkdir -p project/{src,bin,tests}` to create a folder tree in one command.

title: Quickly create a sequence of files
body: Use brace expansion like `touch file{1..10}.txt` to create numbered files.

title: Use !! inside sudo-safe scripts
body: Avoid `sudo !!` in scripts; instead, ensure the script is run with sudo or checks `$(id -u)` == 0.

title: Use set -e in scripts to stop on error
body: Add `set -e` to bash scripts to stop execution when a command returns a non-zero status.

title: Enable strict bash mode
body: Use `set -euo pipefail` and `IFS=$'\n\t'` to make bash scripts safer and fail-fast.

title: Use shellcheck to catch script bugs
body: Run `shellcheck script.sh` to detect common mistakes and bad practices in shell scripts.

title: Use xargs with -0 for safe filenames
body: Combine `find -print0` with `xargs -0` to handle files with spaces, newlines, or special characters.

title: Remove files by pattern using find -delete
body: Use `find . -name '*.tmp' -type f -delete` instead of `rm` to avoid argument list limits.

title: Use ctrl+a and ctrl+e for line navigation
body: In most shells, Ctrl+A jumps to the beginning of the line, and Ctrl+E jumps to the end.

title: Use alt+b and alt+f to move by words
body: Alt+B moves the cursor back one word, Alt+F moves forward one word in the shell.

title: Clear the current line quickly
body: Press Ctrl+U in the shell to clear everything from the cursor to the beginning of the line.

title: Delete from cursor to end with Ctrl+K
body: Use Ctrl+K to delete text from the cursor to the end of the line in readline-based shells.

title: Yank back deleted text with Ctrl+Y
body: After using Ctrl+U or Ctrl+K, use Ctrl+Y to paste (yank) the removed text back.

title: Quickly exit stuck terminal apps with Ctrl+C
body: Press Ctrl+C to send SIGINT to the foreground process, which usually interrupts it.

title: Suspend a process with Ctrl+Z
body: Use Ctrl+Z to pause the current foreground job and send it to the background in a stopped state.

title: Resume suspended jobs in background with bg
body: Type `bg` to continue the most recently suspended job in the background.

title: Bring background jobs to foreground with fg
body: Use `fg` to bring the last backgrounded job back into the foreground.

title: List jobs in the current shell
body: Run `jobs` to see suspended and background jobs associated with the current shell session.

title: Use ps aux for full process listing
body: Run `ps aux | less` to see all processes regardless of user or session.

title: Use pgrep with patterns to find PIDs
body: `pgrep -fl pattern` shows process IDs and names matching a given pattern.

title: Use nice to start low-priority commands
body: Run `nice -n 10 command` to run CPU-heavy tasks with lower priority.

title: Use renice to change priority of running processes
body: `renice +10 -p PID` reduces priority of a running process by its PID.

title: Check kernel messages quickly with dmesg
body: Use `dmesg | tail` to see recent kernel log messages, useful for hardware or driver issues.

title: Filter dmesg output by keyword
body: Use `dmesg | grep -i usb` to quickly see USB-related kernel messages.

title: Use journalctl to view systemd logs
body: Run `journalctl -xe` to see recent detailed logs from systemd-managed services.

title: View logs for a specific systemd service
body: Use `journalctl -u servicename` to display logs related to a single service.

title: Follow systemd logs in real time
body: `journalctl -fu servicename` streams live logs for a particular service.

title: Check system boot logs by boot ID
body: Use `journalctl -b -1` to view logs from the previous boot.

title: Use ncdu for interactive disk usage analysis
body: Run `ncdu /path` to navigate disk usage in a user-friendly TUI and delete files from inside ncdu.

title: Use tree to visualize directories
body: Install `tree` and run `tree -L 2` to see a two-level directory tree.

title: Use lsblk to view block devices
body: Run `lsblk -f` to show disks, partitions, and their filesystems and labels.

title: Find which filesystem a path is on
body: Use `df -h /path` to see which device backs a given directory.

title: See filesystem type with stat -f
body: `stat -f -c %T /path` prints the filesystem type for a directory or file.

title: Quickly extract common archive formats
body: Use `bsdtar -xf archive` or configure `atool` / `dtrx` to auto-detect and extract many formats.

title: Use symbolic links instead of copying data
body: Run `ln -s target linkname` to create a symlink and avoid duplicate files.

title: Quickly open the last edited file in vim
body: Use `vim -c 'normal `0'` or `gvim -S` with sessions to jump back into previous editing context.

title: Use vim as a hex editor
body: In vim, `:%!xxd` switches to hex view; `:%!xxd -r` converts back to regular text.

title: Use nano for quick one-off edits
body: If you’re not comfortable with vim, use `nano` for simple edits and rely on its on-screen help.

title: Enable syntax highlighting in nano
body: Ensure `include "/usr/share/nano/*.nanorc"` is present in `~/.nanorc` for syntax highlighting.

title: Use diff -u for unified diffs
body: Run `diff -u old new` to get a unified diff format, which is easier to read and patch.

title: Ignore whitespace in diffs
body: Use `diff -u -w file1 file2` to ignore all whitespace differences in comparisons.

title: Use colordiff for colored diffs
body: Pipe diff into `colordiff` or use `git diff` with color for more readable diffs.

title: Show only filenames changed in git
body: Use `git diff --name-only` to list files changed without showing the diff details.

title: Use git status -sb for a compact status
body: Run `git status -sb` to see a short, branch-aware summary of repository status.

title: Stash changes in git quickly
body: Use `git stash -u` to temporarily store staged, unstaged, and untracked changes.

title: Use tig as a text-mode git interface
body: `tig` provides an ncurses-based git log and status viewer that’s easier to navigate.

title: Use virtualenv or venv for Python projects
body: Run `python -m venv .venv` and activate it to isolate Python dependencies per project.

title: Use direnv to auto-load environment variables
body: With `direnv`, environment variables defined in `.envrc` are automatically loaded when you cd into a directory.

title: Use .bash_profile vs .bashrc correctly
body: On many systems, `.bashrc` is for interactive shells, `.bash_profile` for login shells; source `.bashrc` from `.bash_profile` for consistency.

title: Persist environment variables system-wide
body: Add environment variables to `/etc/environment` or drop files in `/etc/profile.d` for global shell availability.

title: Use /etc/sudoers.d instead of editing sudoers directly
body: Add custom sudo rules via `/etc/sudoers.d/filename` to avoid breaking the main sudoers file.

title: Always edit sudoers with visudo
body: Use `visudo` to edit sudoers; it performs syntax checking and prevents simultaneous edits.

title: Use ssh config for named hosts
body: Add entries to `~/.ssh/config` to define short host aliases, default users, and keys, e.g. `Host prod`.

title: Use ControlMaster to multiplex SSH connections
body: Configure `ControlMaster auto` in `~/.ssh/config` to reuse a single SSH connection for multiple sessions and speed up ssh and scp.

title: Use ssh -J for jump hosts
body: Use `ssh -J user@jumphost target` or `ProxyJump` in SSH config to reach internal hosts via a bastion.

title: Verify SSH host keys on first connect
body: Check the fingerprint shown by ssh against a trusted source before confirming it to avoid MITM attacks.

title: Disable password SSH login
body: Set `PasswordAuthentication no` in `sshd_config` after configuring key-based access for better security.

title: Use fail2ban to block brute-force attacks
body: Install and configure `fail2ban` to monitor logs and automatically ban IPs with repeated failed logins.

title: Check file permissions quickly with stat
body: `stat -c '%A %a %U %G %n' file` shows human-readable and numeric permissions, owner, and group.

title: Use chmod with symbolic modes
body: Instead of octal, use `chmod u+x` or `chmod g-w` to modify permissions relative to current settings.

title: Preserve attributes when copying with cp -a
body: Use `cp -a src dest` to preserve permissions, timestamps, and symlinks during copy operations.

title: Use mv -n to avoid overwriting files
body: Run `mv -n` to move files without overwriting existing destination files.

title: Use shred for sensitive file deletion
body: Use `shred -u file` to overwrite a file multiple times before deleting it, making recovery harder.

title: Find files by type, not name
body: `find . -type d -maxdepth 2` lists only directories up to a certain depth.

title: Use locate for instant filename search
body: After running `updatedb`, `locate name_part` can find files much faster than a raw find.

title: Limit locate searches to specific directories
body: Use `locate pattern | grep '^/home'` to restrict matches to your home directory.

title: Use ack or ag for searching source code
body: `ack` and `ag` ignore build artifacts and VCS directories, making code searches faster and cleaner.

title: Use ripgrep for blazing-fast grep
body: Install `rg` (ripgrep) and run `rg pattern` to search codebases faster than traditional grep.

title: Use sed -n with p to print selective lines
body: `sed -n '5,10p' file` prints lines 5 through 10 without showing the rest of the file.

title: Replace text in-place safely with sed -i.bak
body: Use `sed -i.bak 's/old/new/g' file` to edit in place while keeping a backup file.bak.

title: Use awk to sum a column of numbers
body: `awk '{sum+=$1} END {print sum}' numbers.txt` calculates the sum of the first column.

title: Format text into columns with column -t
body: Pipe tab- or space-separated text into `column -t` for nicely aligned output.

title: Generate sequences with seq
body: Use `seq 1 10` for 1–10, or `seq 0 5 100` for numbers from 0 to 100 in steps of 5.

title: Quickly generate random numbers with shuf
body: Use `shuf -i 1-100 -n 1` to get a random number between 1 and 100.

title: Create temporary files safely with mktemp
body: `mktemp` creates a unique temporary filename or directory, avoiding collisions and race conditions.

title: Use env to test commands with modified variables
body: Run `env VAR=value command` to temporarily set or override an environment variable for a single command.

title: Use printf instead of echo for portability
body: `printf` handles escape sequences more predictably than `echo`, especially for `\n` and `-e` differences across shells.

title: Use command substitution with $(...) instead of backticks
body: `$(...)` is easier to read and nest than legacy backtick command substitution.

title: Use [[ ]] in bash for safer conditionals
body: `[[ ... ]]` avoids many quoting pitfalls of `[ ... ]` and supports pattern matching.

title: Use case statements instead of many ifs
body: Bash `case` statements can simplify multiple string comparisons and make scripts easier to read.

title: Use getopts to parse script options
body: Bash’s `getopts` builtin lets you handle `-f` and `-o value` style options robustly.

title: Redirect stderr separately from stdout
body: Use `command >out.log 2>err.log` to separate standard output from error messages.

title: Merge stderr into stdout when piping
body: Use `command 2>&1 | tee log` to capture both stdout and stderr into a single stream.

title: Silence both stdout and stderr
body: Use `command >/dev/null 2>&1` to discard all output from a command.

title: Check open files for a process with lsof -p
body: `lsof -p PID` lists all files, sockets, and devices opened by a given process ID.

title: Find who is using a filesystem with fuser
body: `fuser -vm /mountpoint` shows processes using files under /mountpoint.

title: Use watch -d to highlight differences
body: Run `watch -d '<command>'` to highlight changes in the output between iterations.

title: Monitor CPU usage per process with pidstat
body: `pidstat 1` shows per-process CPU usage every second.

title: Monitor disk I/O per process with iotop
body: Run `sudo iotop` to see which processes are generating the most disk I/O.

title: Check per-CPU usage with mpstat
body: `mpstat -P ALL 1` shows per-CPU usage in 1-second intervals.

title: Use sar to record historical performance
body: Configure `sar` to collect CPU, memory, and I/O stats for long-term analysis.

title: Check open network connections with netstat or ss
body: Use `ss -tunap` to list active TCP/UDP connections and owning processes.

title: Test TCP connectivity with nc
body: `nc -vz host port` quickly checks if a TCP port is accepting connections.

title: Send simple HTTP requests with nc
body: Use `printf 'GET / HTTP/1.0\r\n\r\n' | nc host 80` to manually test HTTP servers.

title: Throttle download speed with curl
body: Use `curl --limit-rate 200k URL` to limit bandwidth usage when downloading files.

title: Resume interrupted downloads with wget -c
body: Use `wget -c URL` to continue downloading a partially retrieved file.

title: Mirror a site recursively with wget
body: `wget -m -p -E -k URL` creates a local mirror of a website for offline viewing.

title: Use curl -I to fetch HTTP headers only
body: Run `curl -I URL` to see response headers like status, server type, and cache info without downloading the body.

title: Debug DNS resolution with dig +trace
body: `dig +trace example.com` lets you see the DNS resolution path step by step.

title: Check DNS records from specific server
body: Use `dig @8.8.8.8 example.com A` to query a specific DNS server for a record.

title: Use tcpdump to capture specific traffic
body: Run `sudo tcpdump -i eth0 port 80` to capture HTTP traffic on eth0.

title: Write tcpdump capture to file for Wireshark
body: `sudo tcpdump -i eth0 -w capture.pcap` saves packets to a file you can analyze later.

title: Use ip addr instead of ifconfig
body: Run `ip addr` to list IP addresses and interfaces, replacing the older ifconfig tool.

title: Use ip route to inspect routing table
body: `ip route` shows the current routing table and default gateway configuration.

title: Temporarily add an IP address to an interface
body: Use `sudo ip addr add 192.0.2.10/24 dev eth0` to add an additional IP for testing.

title: Flush DNS cache on systemd-resolved systems
body: Run `sudo resolvectl flush-caches` to clear cached DNS entries.

title: Use hostnamectl to set hostname
body: `sudo hostnamectl set-hostname newname` changes the system hostname in a systemd-friendly way.

title: List available locales on the system
body: Run `locale -a` to see all installed locales.

title: Convert line endings with dos2unix
body: Use `dos2unix file` to convert Windows CRLF line endings to Unix LF.

title: Use iconv to convert text encodings
body: `iconv -f ISO-8859-1 -t UTF-8 input > output` converts file encodings safely.

title: Sort unique lines with sort -u
body: Use `sort -u file` to sort lines and remove duplicates in one step.

title: Use grep -v to exclude matches
body: `grep -v pattern file` prints all lines that do NOT match the pattern.

title: Use egrep or grep -E for extended regex
body: Extended regexes with `grep -E 'foo|bar'` allow more powerful patterns like alternation and grouping.

title: Use grep -o to show only matching parts
body: Run `grep -o '[0-9]\+' file` to print only the numeric matches, not entire lines.

title: Highlight matches with GREP_OPTIONS
body: Export `GREP_OPTIONS='--color=auto'` or configure your shell so `grep` highlights matches by default.

title: Use bat as a modern alternative to cat
body: `bat file` shows syntax-highlighted content with line numbers and git integration.

title: Use exa as a modern ls replacement
body: Install `exa` and use `exa -lh --git` for colorful listings with git status indicators.

title: Use tldr for simplified command help
body: `tldr command` shows concise, example-driven explanations compared to full man pages.

title: Save frequently used one-liners as shell functions
body: Define a bash function in `~/.bashrc` like `mkcd(){ mkdir -p "$1" && cd "$1"; }` for convenient re-use.

title: Use command -v to test if a command exists
body: In scripts, `command -v tool >/dev/null 2>&1` checks whether an executable is available.

title: Lock your screen from the terminal
body: Use `loginctl lock-session` or desktop-specific tools like `gnome-screensaver-command -l`.

title: Use xclip or xsel to access X11 clipboard
body: Pipe text to `xclip -selection clipboard` to copy it to the GUI clipboard from the terminal.

title: Record your terminal session with script
body: `script session.log` records all terminal input and output to a file for later review.

title: Use watch with git status during rebase
body: `watch -n 1 'git status -sb'` helps visualize progress during complex rebases.

title: Use sshfs to mount remote directories
body: `sshfs user@server:/path ~/remote` lets you interact with remote files as if they were local.

title: Use fusermount -u to unmount FUSE filesystems
body: Run `fusermount -u ~/remote` or `umount` depending on your distro to detach sshfs mounts.

title: Use nohup for commands that survive logout
body: Run `nohup command &` so a long-running process continues even if you disconnect.

title: Use disown to detach jobs from your shell
body: `disown -h %1` removes a job from the shell’s job table so it won’t receive hangup signals.

title: List setuid and setgid binaries for security review
body: Use `find / -xdev -type f \( -perm -4000 -o -perm -2000 \) -ls` to find SUID/SGID programs.

title: Check password strength with cracklib-check
body: Pipe candidate passwords into `cracklib-check` to detect weak ones before using them.

title: List recently installed packages
body: On Debian-based systems, `grep ' install ' /var/log/dpkg.log` shows recent package installations.

title: Find which package owns a file
body: Use `dpkg -S /path/file` on Debian or `rpm -qf /path/file` on RPM-based systems.

title: List package contents before installing
body: On Debian, `apt-file show pkg` (with apt-file installed) lets you inspect files included in a package.

title: Use apt-get source to download package source
body: `apt-get source package` fetches the source code for a Debian package for inspection or patching.

title: Use strace to debug syscalls of a process
body: Run `strace -p PID` to see system calls a process is making in real time.

title: Use ltrace to debug dynamic library calls
body: `ltrace` shows calls into shared libraries, which can be useful for reverse engineering.

title: Attach gdb to a running process
body: Use `gdb -p PID` to investigate crashy or stuck processes interactively.

title: Use core dumps for post-mortem debugging
body: Enable core dumps with `ulimit -c unlimited` and configure `/proc/sys/kernel/core_pattern`.

title: Use perf top for live CPU hot spot analysis
body: `sudo perf top` shows which functions consume most CPU in real time.

title: Use perf record and perf report for profiling sessions
body: Run `perf record command` then `perf report` to analyze CPU usage by code paths.

title: Use cpulimit to restrict CPU usage of a process
body: `cpulimit -p PID -l 20` limits a process to 20% CPU, helpful on shared systems.

title: Use ionice to lower a process’s I/O priority
body: Run `ionice -c3 command` to reduce its disk I/O priority and avoid impacting other workloads.

title: Check swap usage and performance impact
body: `vmstat 1` and `free -h` together show swap-in/out activity and memory pressure.

title: Use swappiness to tune swap behavior
body: Lower `/proc/sys/vm/swappiness` (e.g. to 10) to reduce kernel eagerness to swap out pages.

title: Use tmpfs for fast, volatile storage
body: Mount a tmpfs at `/mnt/ramdisk` for extremely fast but non-persistent files.

title: Compress backups on the fly with pigz
body: `tar cf - dir | pigz > backup.tar.gz` uses parallel compression for faster backups on multi-core CPUs.

title: Use rsync --link-dest for efficient snapshots
body: Use `rsync -a --link-dest=prev/ src/ snapshot/` to create deduplicated backup snapshots using hard links.

title: Use logrotate to keep logs from filling disks
body: Configure `/etc/logrotate.d/` entries so large logs are rotated, compressed, and pruned automatically.

title: Use cron for periodic tasks
body: Add jobs with `crontab -e` in the format `*/5 * * * * command` for timed automation.

title: Use systemd timers instead of cron
body: Create `.timer` and `.service` units for more robust scheduling with logging via systemd.

title: Use anacron for tasks on machines that aren’t always on
body: Anacron runs periodic jobs that may have been missed while the machine was powered off.

title: Use hostname -I to list all IPs on the host
body: `hostname -I` prints all non-loopback IP addresses assigned to the system.

title: Use yes to stress-test commands reading from stdin
body: `yes | command` feeds endless "y" lines to test how commands behave under continuous input.

title: Use /dev/urandom for quick random data
body: `head -c 32 /dev/urandom | base64` produces random base64 strings for tokens.

title: Use /dev/zero to create sparse test files
body: `dd if=/dev/zero of=file bs=1M count=0 seek=1024` creates a sparse 1 GiB file instantly.

title: Use file to identify file formats
body: `file something` uses magic numbers to guess the type of a binary or text file.

title: Verify binary dependencies with ldd
body: Run `ldd /path/to/binary` to see which shared libraries an executable requires.

title: Check environment variables of a running process
body: Inspect `/proc/<pid>/environ` (with `tr '\0' '\n'`) to see a process’s environment.

title: Use watch free -h to monitor memory usage
body: `watch -n 1 free -h` shows RAM and swap behavior over time.

title: Use top’s interactive filters
body: In `top`, press `o` to add filters (e.g. `COMMAND=nginx`) and narrow down processes.

title: Use htop’s tree view
body: Press F5 in `htop` to see processes in a tree structure, making parent-child relationships clear.

title: Customize your prompt with PS1
body: Set `PS1` to include `\u`, `\h`, `\w`, and git info for a helpful shell prompt.

title: Use starship as a cross-shell prompt
body: Install `starship` and add `eval "$(starship init bash)"` to get a colorful informative prompt in many shells.

title: Use zsh with oh-my-zsh for productivity
body: Zsh plus `oh-my-zsh` provides autosuggestions, plugins, and themes that speed up command-line work.

title: Use fzf with Ctrl+R for fuzzy history search
body: Integrate `fzf` so `Ctrl+R` uses fuzzy search, making it much easier to find complex old commands.

title: Use autojump or zoxide to jump to frequent folders
body: Tools like `autojump` and `zoxide` learn your movements and let you jump to directories by typing partial names.

title: Use dircolors to customize ls colors
body: Edit or generate `~/.dir_colors` and run `eval "$(dircolors)"` to change color schemes for ls and compatible tools.

title: Use ripgrep + fd + fzf as a modern CLI trio
body: Combine `fd` for finding files, `rg` for searching, and `fzf` for fuzzy filtering to navigate projects quickly.

title: Use docker ps --format for custom listings
body: `docker ps --format '{{.ID}} {{.Image}} {{.Names}}'` prints only the fields you care about.

title: Limit container resources with Docker flags
body: Use `docker run --memory 512m --cpus 1` to prevent a container from hogging system resources.

title: Use docker-compose for multi-container setups
body: Define services in `docker-compose.yml` to manage and network multiple containers as one stack.

title: Use docker logs -f for streaming app logs
body: `docker logs -f container` is handy for following logs while developing or debugging services.

title: Use docker exec -it to debug inside containers
body: `docker exec -it container bash` lets you inspect the container’s filesystem and processes interactively.

title: Use du -xh --max-depth=1 to find large directories
body: Run `du -xh --max-depth=1` in a path to see which subdirectories consume the most space, in human-readable units.

title: Use journalctl --disk-usage to see log size
body: `journalctl --disk-usage` reports how much space systemd-journald logs currently occupy.

title: Use timedatectl to check time sync status
body: `timedatectl` shows whether NTP or other synchronization is active and what time source is in use.

title: Use who and w to see logged-in users
body: `who` lists who is logged in; `w` adds what they’re doing and their idle time.

title: Use last to inspect login history
body: `last` shows recent logins, reboots, and shut downs, useful for auditing access.

title: Use alias rm='rm -i' to avoid accidental deletions
body: Interactive `rm` prompts before deleting each file, reducing the risk of mistakes.

title: Use trash-cli instead of rm for recoverable deletes
body: `trash-put file` moves items to the desktop trash, letting you restore them later.

title: Use ncdu before deleting large directories
body: `ncdu /path` lets you interactively browse and delete large subdirectories, reducing mistakes.

title: Use env | sort to see environment cleanly
body: `env | sort` lists environment variables alphabetically, making duplicates easier to spot.

title: Use history -d to remove sensitive commands
body: Use `history -d <line>` then `history -w` to remove a line from the history file.

title: Avoid storing secrets in shell history
body: Prefer `read -s var` or environment variables instead of typing passwords directly into commands.

title: Use systemctl list-unit-files to see service enablement
body: `systemctl list-unit-files --type=service` shows which services are enabled, disabled, or masked.

title: Mask dangerous or unused services
body: `systemctl mask service` prevents it from being started manually or automatically.

title: Use systemctl edit to override service settings
body: `systemctl edit service` creates drop-in config overrides that survive package upgrades.

title: Use man hier to understand Linux filesystem layout
body: `man hier` explains standard directory purpose such as /etc, /usr, /var, and /home.

title: Use info pages for deeper GNU documentation
body: Some tools have more detailed `info` documentation beyond the man page, e.g. `info coreutils`.

title: Use apropos to discover commands by description
body: `apropos keyword` searches man page descriptions for relevant commands.

title: Use locate + updatedb in cron for nightly index
body: Schedule `updatedb` to run at night so `locate` always has a fresh file index.

title: Use gzip -9 for maximum compression
body: Increase compression ratio at the cost of CPU time with `gzip -9 file`.

title: Use pv to show progress of pipelines
body: Insert `pv` in pipelines, e.g. `pv bigfile | gzip > bigfile.gz`, to see transfer progress.

title: Use watch -n 0.5 for high-frequency checks
body: When diagnosing race conditions, `watch -n 0.5 command` updates twice per second.

title: Use tee to split output for logging and processing
body: `command | tee output.log | another-command` lets you log and continue pipelining simultaneously.

title: Use cmp to compare binary files
body: Run `cmp -l file1 file2` to see the first differing byte between two binary files.

title: Use truncate to quickly resize files
body: `truncate -s 0 file` empties a file without deleting it; `truncate -s 10M file` sets an exact size.
